ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this history of astronomical knowledge developed by cultures around the world prior to the telescope; celestial navigation skills; how different calendar systems work; how to use historical timekeeping and astronomical measurement devices
I learned some basic knowledge regarding various coordinate systems, the motion of stars and planets as seen from Earth, and different astronomical features that were significant to ancient cultures.
I learned about naked-eye astronomy techniques and how ancient cultures used astronomy.
History of astronomy and basic naked eye observing
History of astronomy around the world. Development of modern astronomy revealed the euro-centric nature of the field
A good background for naked eye astronomy and the history of archeoastronomy.
I got a vague understanding of basic astronomical and historical astrological principles and topics. I dont think I developed any new skills or insights.
I learned a lot about the intersection between science and culture, especially how they affect each other.
Gained greater awareness about the night sky, our position in the solar system and how ancient people interpreted the stars and seasons before telescopes.
Knowledge of astronomy and world cultures

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: course format was really well designed for a virtual semester, content was always engaging, professor and TA were very accessible with lots of office hour time and quick email responses. lecture content fit very well with the weekly reading assignments, which were way more interesting and easier to understand than typical readings in other courses, all of the lecture content and assignments were very organized and posted well in advance of lectures/due dates. pset questions allowed us to engage deeply with course content without being unnecessarily hard: if you do the readings and watch the videos, the homework is easy. the final paper about whatever we want related to the course is fun too, and also a very manageable length. class discussion did not really teach any new information than what was in the lecture videos and didn't always feel necessary.

I thought that the course was designed very well. I always enjoyed attending class sessions due to the enthusiastic and relaxed atmosphere, and developed some basic astronomical and cultural knowledge that I have found myself applying in everyday situations.
Strengths: The material is pretty interesting. Weaknesses: The problem sets can be a bit tedious.

Weekly problem sets seem a bit unnecessary and sometimes remedial. I also wish we could have dedicated more time to and focused more on non-European sky cultures given they're inherently not as well-known by students today.

This course is organized terribly for student learning. The lectures are of lower quality and depth than most YouTube informational videos, and section is absolutely useless. Problem sets are often abstruse and didnt actually develop insight or skillone literally involved counting dates to a hundred and eighty days for an exercise. No assignment here felt like it actually provided value or helped me learn except the final paper.
Obviously impossible in the circumstances, but it would have been great to have had time in the observatory

Strength was the material, super interesting

Weakness was the assignments, they felt like busy work. More project based might have been more interesting

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the short pre-recorded videos and in-class discussion of lecture content worked really well for this course since the content is not math/physics/theory heavy. This style of teaching is great information like this that can be absorbed, but should NEVER be recommended for a physics-intensive course where being able to ask questions during the lecture is essential.
I have no complaints; I thought that the structure of watching lectures beforehand was good, and I thought that the breakout room discussions were probably the best I've had during  COVID times.
The small-group discussion format didn't translate super well to Zoom, as participation in breakout rooms can be a bit hit-or-miss. The recorded lectures worked well, though.
The pre-recorded lectures were very well done. Professor Faison is very technologically literate and helpful
I dont think the conversion to a flipped classroom was a success. Normal Lectures would have been much better.
It was really difficult to feel engaged with the material when there werent more actual observing sessions that would normally be held in person
Recorded lectures were well done and great to have to rewatch
Live discussion instead of live lecture was good

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!

Absolutely. This course is wonderful. You leave the course having learned some foundational knowledge about a whole range of topics (both scientific and cultural), while having a good time throughout. Dr. Faison is very easy to get along with, flexible, fair, and knowledgeable. The problem sets were sometimes a little more involved than I had anticipated, but I got a lot out of doing them - and most questions were open-ended enough that they enabled students to explore the subjects to the extent that they wished.

Yes, as a humanities student, this course was an interesting and accessible way to fulfill my science distribution requirement. The course did a good job introducing basic astronomical concepts and then pivoting to a more cultural focus. The only drawback was that the problem sets are somewhat tedious.
yes, its very interesting, and is easy to pick up
Absolutely, for astro majors and non astro majors.

I would not. The material, while interesting in theory, is taught like a high school class, with all the boredom and superficiality that entails. The grading is often mechanical, inflexible, and sometimes wrong. The material we learned is around the level of skimming a pop science book.
Yes
I would recommend this class to students who are looking for an astronomy course that isnt too math-heavy.
I would recommend this course to another student
I would recommend this to anyone interested in the night sky or ancient civilizations.
Yes. One of the most interesting classes Ive taken at yale, eye-opening connections between history and science.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lectures to be watched in advance of virtual discussion sections that took place during the scheduled class meeting time
We watched lectures before class and then had class discussions (e.g., breakout room questions and Q&A with the instructor) during class time.
recorded lectures plus live zoom chats during class time
Pre-recorded lecture and live virtual discussion
In person section
recorded lecture and virtual seminar or other discussion format
Virtual discussion and recorded lecture
Recorded lectures and in person lecture/seminar
Recorded lecture, live zoom discussion
